Award.AwardTitle: REU/RET Site: Interdisciplinary Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) and Teachers (RET) in Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL PART: This project will provide 10 undergraduate students each summer with an introduction to materials research while encouraging interested students to pursue a graduate degree in a materials-related field. During the 10-week program, students will participate in independent research projects under the guidance of Cornell faculty. A stimulating cohort experience will be created through a leadership workshop, weekly seminars, field trips, a presentation workshop, a concluding symposium, and a variety of informal activities. In addition, a teacher-training program that specifically targets teachers in schools that serve large underrepresented minority and low socioeconomic status populations will increase student achievement in science by providing professional development activities for 5 middle school and high school teachers per year. The two-summer progressive program will include both a six-week team-research experience that introduces teachers to materials research as well as a six-week independent research experience to enable in-depth exploration. Both programs will include curriculum development activities.


TECHNICAL PART: An exceedingly wide variety of scientific and engineering research will be accomplished under this program, exploring materials-related topics in biomaterials, energy, soft materials, and hard materials. Individual projects will range from the development of new materials for high performance batteries to studies of mechanical properties degradation in injured cartilage to the computational design of materials for next-generation microelectronics. With the guidance of top researchers and their groups, participating undergraduates and teachers will construct scientific apparatus, perform experiments, model material properties, analyze data, and contribute to the general materials knowledge base and to their own education and training.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Research Experience for Undergraduate Site program provided 33 undergraduate students with an introduction to materials research and encouraged students to pursue a graduate degree in material-related field. During the 10-week program that was offered each summer from 2015-2017, each student worked alongside faculty, postdocs, and graduate students on a carefully selected research topic. The student also participated in group meetings to learn about research of the other members of the lab and to present the progress of their own research. The research program also provided a number of professional development activities.

An additional objective of the program was to give undergraduates a better understanding of the interdisciplinary nature of materials research and employment opportunities in the field. The students participated in Hot Materials seminar series, a field trip to Corning Inc., and a panel discussed life as a graduate student and the graduate admissions process.

 Intellectual Merit: A wide array of scientific and engineering research was accomplished under this program. The REU projects resulted in publications in science and engineering journals. 

Broader Impacts: The program educated an outstanding and diverse group of young women and men in materials research thereby encouraging the development of a diverse STEM workforce. During this last funding period, 57% of the students were from underrepresented populations, 64% were females, 7% identified a disability, and 57% were from institutions with limited research opportunities. The survey found that 90% of the students stated that their interest in a career in research increased as a result of their REU experience and 81% indicated that the REU experience was important in their decision to go to apply to graduate school. 

The objective of the Research Experience for Teachers (RET) program was to increase student achievement in science by providing professional development activities for middle school and high school teachers of mathematics, science, and technology. The RET program provided teachers an opportunity to develop curriculum based on the research they learned on campus and the possibility of returning for a second summer to conduct an independent research project with faculty. 

Intellectual Merit: The Research Experience for Teachers program enabled teachers who taught a diverse group of students to spend six weeks participating in hands-on research projects and developing materials-related curriculum for classroom use. During this period, the teachers learned about new innovations and experimental techniques with the facility managers and faculty. All the materials developed by the teachers are archived on the CCMR website where they are available for educators nationwide. 

Broader impact: The RET program impacted student interest in science and engineering by providing professional development to middle and high school teachers. During the last period, the teachers were from low socioeconomic schools and from minority-serving schools.
